Hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol as a model compound of bio-oil in methanol over mesoporous noble metal catalysts E.A. Roldugina E.R. Naranov A.L. Maximov E.A. Karakhanov ⁎ Department of Chemistry, Lomonosov Moscow State University, Moscow, 119991, Russia Department of Chemistry Lomonosov Moscow State University Moscow 119991 Russia ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The liquid phase hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of guaiacol (GUA), a model compound of bio-oil, was studied on bimetallic (PtPd) and monometallic (Ru) catalysts supported on mesoporous aluminosilicate of Al-HMS(X) type with different Si/Al (X) ratios and on mesoporous zirconia modified with silica (m-ZrO2-SiO2) in the presence of methanol as a solvent. The catalysts were characterized by NH3-TPD, TEM, XPS, 27Al and 29Si solid-state NMR and N2 adsorption–desorption methods. The inﬂuence of сatalyst loading, temperature, solvent/guaiacol ratio and contact time on the catalytic performance was investigated. It was established that, decreasing the Si/Al ratio and, correspondingly, increasing the acidity of the catalysts based on Al-HMS led to increasing conversion of guaiacol. Phenol, catechol, and their methylated derivatives were the main products of guaiacol HDO reaction in methanol at low catalyst loading (guaiacol/metal ratio, 800). It was found that the fraction of completely hydrodeoxygenated products (cyclohexane and methylcyclohexane) greatly increased as the catalyst loading grew (guaiacol/metal ratio, 160). Conversion of guaiacol on PtPd/m-ZrO2-SiO2 catalyst was higher than that on PtPd/Al-HMS(10), in accordance with the larger number of acid sites on the catalyst surface; however, the undesirable heavy fraction of methylated by-products was also higher. Ru-based catalysts exhibited the highest catalytic activity and showed unusually high selectivity toward fully hydrodeoxygenated products (cyclohexane, methylcyclohexane) in the HDO of guaiacol in the presence of methanol. Guaiacol can be efficiently converted into alkanes, with quantitative conversion and selectivity to cyclohexanes of 78% over Ru/Al-HMS(10) catalyst under relatively mild conditions (200 °C, 5 MPa H2). Methylation under the influence of methanol, deoxygenation on acid sites and aromatic ring hydrogenation on metal sites proceeded in a parallel way according to the suggested reaction pathways. Keywords Hydrodeoxygenation Guaiacol Pt Pd Ru Bio-oil Al-HMS Mesoporous zirconia 1 Introduction Under conditions of power-intensive industrial development, new effective and renewable liquid fuels and chemicals with a minimal environmental affect are required. The partial replacement of oil by biofuel for the production of transportation fuel is a problem of considerable current interest regarding environmental science, chemistry, and engineering. Lignin-cellulose biomass (agricultural and timber wastes) is a raw material for the production of biofuel. Through fast pyrolysis, the biomass is rapidly heated in the absence of oxygen to produce liquid products referred to as bio-oil in addition to combustible gas and coal. Bio-oil is a tentative name because major organic compound classes identified in bio-oil are carboxylic acids, alcohols, aldehydes, ketones, furans and phenolics. A large variability in the concentration of any particular compound in the bio-oil is related to using different types of woody materials for bio-oil production or different pyrolysis conditions. Bio-oil cannot be directly used as transportation fuel because of high water (15–30wt%) and oxygen contents, poor chemical stability and immiscibility with hydrocarbon fuels; therefore, its further processing is required [1]. Hydrodeoxygenation is a process similar to hydrofining performed to improve the quality of bio-oil; in the course of this process, oxygen-containing phenolic compounds are converted into cycloalkanes, which are more effective energy carriers [2]. Unlike catalytic cracking, in the HDO oxygen is removed from the components of bio-oil primarily forming water; because of this, the yields of liquid hydrocarbons are considerably higher. Guaiacol is frequently used in the HDO process as a model compound because it contains both hydroxyl (-OH) and methoxy (-OCH3) groups which are most typical for lignin-derived phenolic monomers [3]. Traditional sulfided hydrotreating catalysts (NiMo, CoMo) were explored by the majority of researchers for the HDO of bio-oil [4–6]. However, these catalysts possess some essential disadvantages, such as rapid deactivation under the HDO conditions, the need for preliminary sulfurization, and high temperatures of experiments [7]. As an alternative, non-sulfide systems based on transition metals Ni [8–10], Mo [11,12] or Fe [13] were used for HDO reactions. Furthermore, NiMo carbide [14], Mo nitride [15,16], and supported metal phosphides (Ni2P/SiO2, Fe2P/SiO2, MoP/SiO2,Co2P/SiO2 and WP/SiO2) [17,18] were reported. The major products from the HDO of guaiacol for the most active phosphides were benzene and phenol [17]. Transition metal-based catalysts exhibit high activity in the HDO reaction; however, they possess low resistance to water in an acid medium and are prone to coking at elevated temperatures [19]. Catalysts based on noble metals (Rh, Ru, Pt, and Pd) are characterized by high activity in the HDO of both phenolic model compounds and real bio-oil [20–22]. The advantage of these catalysts is their high stability due to increased resistance to deactivation through coking [23]. Gutierrez et al. [23] studied the HDO of guaiacol over different ZrO2-supported catalysts and found that the activity decreases as follows: Rh ≈ RhPt > RhPd > Pd > Pt > PdPt. Lee et al. [24] obtained complete conversion of guaiacol over Ru,Rh,Pt and Pd-containing catalysts supported on Al2O3, SiO2-Al2O3 and carbon.The highest selectivity for fully hydrogenated and deoxygenated product-cyclohexane (60%) was obtained for Ru/SiO2-Al2O3. Distribution of guaiacol HDO reaction products depends not only on the active noble metal but also, to a greater extent, on the properties of the support [24]. γ-Al2O3 [25–27] was used as a support in the initial research of bio-oil HDO, however, γ-Al2O3 is converted into boehmite AlO(OH) in the presence of water formed in HDO reactions [28]. The intensity of coke formation on Al2O3 surface, which correlates to high acidity of the support, should be taken into consideration [25]. According to this, active carbon materials can be used as a support providing low coke formation because of the lack of acid sites [29–31]. The disadvantage of carbon supports is that regeneration based on oxidation of poisons cannot be used for these materials. They also possess low ability to remove oxygen-containing groups from bio-oil phenolic compounds due to their low acidity [1]. To overcome these flaws, many support materials such as zeolites [32–34], SiO2 [35], TiO2 [25], CeO2 [36] and ZrO2 [7,23,25,29,37] were explored in recent years. High catalytic activity of ZrO2 seems to favor activation of O-compounds on the support surface [7,23,25]. However, the surface area of ZrO2 is very small, which is unfavorable for the improvement of catalytic performance. The addition of SiO2 into ZrO2 may overcome this disadvantage [38]. There has been little research on the application of mesoporous materials as a support in the HDO reactions. Wang et al. [39] used a platinum catalyst based on mesoporous zeolite ZSM-5 for the HDO of bio-oil (200 °C, 4 MPa); the degree of deoxygenation on this catalyst was much higher than that on non-mesoporous γ-Al2O3. Materials based on SBA-15, HMS, SBA-16, and DMS-1 were used as supports in the HDO of bio-oil [40]. The activity of hydrofining catalysts decreased in the following order: SBA-15 > HMS > SBA 16 >> DMS. Yu et al. [41] carried out the HDO of guaiacol (250 °C, 4 MPa) over Pt/Al-SBA-15(X) catalyst with different Si/Al ratios (X = 20,40, and 80). Cyclohexane was the main reaction product. The higher activity for materials with a lower Si/Al ratio was found [41,42]. Phenol and benzene were observed as the major products in the gas-phase HDO of guaiacol on the NiCo/Al-MCM-41 catalyst (350 °C, H2/guaiacol = 25). Also methylated products (toluene, cresol, other C7–12) were reported as a result of methyl transfer reaction over the acidic function of mesoporous support [43]. Recently, Pt supported mesoporous CeO2 and ZrO2 catalyst was found to perform well in the HDO of phenol to cyclohexanone, cyclohexanol and cyclohexane [44]. Thereby, mesoporous materials possess a considerable hydrothermal stability, ordered structure, controllable pore diameters, and a high specific surface area. The pore size is greater than the molecular dimensions of the majority of raw material components, which leads to high catalytic activity through a decrease in diffusion limitations preventing the access of reactants to the surface [45,46]. Moreover, the support should have a large number of acid sites active in the HDO temperature range (150–450 °C), but the presence of strong acid sites facilitates the occurrence of side reactions with a decrease in the yield of target products [25]. The use of mesoporous materials based on metal oxides (Al, Si, Zr) with various acidic and textural characteristics controlled at the synthesis stage seems very promising. The reactions of guaiacol were mostly studied either in the solution of a long-chain hydrocarbon [23,27,32,33] or in the gas-phase hydrogenation [43,47,48]. Thereto, real bio-oil (pH∼3) contains a large number (up to ∼35wt%) of polar, low-molecular weight compounds: acids (formic, acetic, propanoic), alcohols (methanol, ethanol, ethylene glycol), esters (methyl formate, butyrolactone), ketones (acetone, hydroxyacetone), aldehydes (acetaldehyde, formaldehyde, glyoxal) etc., substantially affecting the HDO of bio-oil-derived phenolic compounds [49]. In this context, methanol was chosen as the solvent in the liguid phase HDO of guaiacol to investigate the influence of polar, low-molecular weight components of bio-oil on catalytic activity and HDO pathways. Addition of methanol keeps bio-oil homogenous, reduces its density and viscosity and inhibits reactions aging [50]. In the absence of initial H2, methanol can also act as a hydrogen donor [51]. Therefore, in this work, we studied the liquid phase HDO of guaiacol on PtPd and Ru-containing catalysts based on mesoporous zirconia-silica and aluminosilicates in the presence of methanol. The HDO of guaiacol was performed at different reaction factors: temperature (200–400 °C) and reaction time (3–6 h) under 5 MPa of H2. The reaction mechanism of hydrodeoxygenation in the presence of methanol as a solvent was suggested. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of mesoporous supports Mesoporous aluminosilicates were synthesized in the presence of C16H33NH2 (Acros Organics) template; Si(OC2H5)4 (Acros Organics) was used as a source of silicon and Al(OCH[CH3]C2H5)3 (Sigma–Aldrich) was used as a source of aluminum. A certain amount of water was added to the mixture containing isopropanol, Si(OC2H5)4 and Al(OCH[CH3]C2H5)3 (with Si/Al molar ratios of 10, 40 and 100); then, the mixture was added to the aqueous solution of a template at 30 °C, and the contents were allowed to stand for 20–40 h. The precipitate was filtered, dried at 110 °C, and calcined in the air at 650 °C. Cetyltrimmethylammonium bromide (CTAB) C19H42BrN (Merck) was chosen as a surfactant in the synthesis of mesoporous m-ZrO2-SiO2. The aqueous solution of Zr(SO4)2·4H2O (Alfa Aesar) was added to the aqueous solution of the surfactant. The mixture was stirred at 25 °C for 2 h and allowed to stand at 95 °C for 48 h. The resulting materials were dried and washed with water to reach a pH value of ∼5. On stabilization with silica, distilled water was initially added to ZrO2; then, the calculated quantity of silicon oxide (Sigma–Aldrich) in the mixture of distilled water and 35% TEA-OH solution (Acros) was added. The mixture was exposed to heating at 90 °C for 24 h; the precipitate was filtered, washed with water (pH ∼7), dried initially at room temperature and then in the argon atmosphere for 2 h at 200 °C, and calcined in the air at 550 °C for 6 h. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The samples of supports were calcined at 400 °C for 2 h and cooled in the dry argon atmosphere at 200 °C before impregnation. Then PtPd catalysts were prepared by the wet co-impregnation method using aqueous solution of H2PtCl6·6H2O (Sigma-Aldrich, ≥37.50% Pt) and PdCl2 (Aurat, 99.95%, ≥59% Pd) in 0.02M HCl. The amounts of Pt and Pd in bimetallic catalysts were 0.25 and 1wt%, respectively. To prepare Ru catalysts, the calculated quantity of a support was added to the solution of RuCl3 (Aurat, 99.95%, ≥47.8% Ru) in 70 ml methanol while stirring for 6 h until the formation of a homogeneous mixture. Methanol was removed on a rotary evaporator. The amount of Ru in monometallic catalysts was 1%wt. The catalysts obtained were dried in the flow of air at 60 °C for 6 h and reduced in the flow of H2 at 400 °C for 2 h. PtPd-containing systems are used as catalysts of hydrotreating in existing refinery, where in the total content of metals in the catalyst should not exceed 1–1.3wt%, which is associated with economic aspects of using noble metal catalysts. Because of the high cost of Pt-containing catalysts, refineries employ catalysts that contain no more than 0.25–0.3wt% of Pt. Moreover, catalysts with «0.25%Pt1%Pd/mesoporous aluminosilicate»-structure were previously investigated by our group in the hydrotreating fractions of traditional oil, what caused the investigation of the same catalysts in the hydrotreating of bio-oil [45]. Ru-containing systems have been developed for the first time based on literature data on hydrodeoxygenation of bio-oil, according to which, catalysts containing 1wt% Ru were mostly researched. In addition, metal loading determines the cost of the final catalyst. It can be assumed, that as Ru content increases, the surface area decreases and the size of Ru particles increases, which can negatively affects the catalytic activity [52–54]. 2.3 Catalysts characterization Textural characteristics were determined from nitrogen adsorption measurements carried out at −196 °C on а Micromeritics Gemini VII 2390 V1.02t analyzer in accordance with the standard procedure. The total surface area and pore volume were determined using the BET equation. The pore size distribution curves were calculated by BJH method. The TEM images of the samples of the mesoporous supports and bifunctional catalysts were obtained on a JEM-2100 (JEOL, Japan) electron microscope with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The samples for the TEM study were prepared by the ultrasonic dispersing in ethanol and consequent deposition of the suspension upon a holey carbon ﬁlm supported on a copper grid. Local elemental analysis was performed by the EDX method on an Oxford Energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer equipped with Si(Li) detector with an energy resolution of 130 eV. The acidity of mesoporous materials was determined by the NH3-TPD on a USGA-101 instrument (UNISIT, Russia). The test sample of ∼0.1 g with a particle size of 0.5–0.25 mm was placed in a quartz reactor and treated in a flow of helium at 500 °C for 1 h with the subsequent blowing with nitrogen. Saturation was performed in a flow of dried ammonia diluted with nitrogen at the temperature of 60 °C for 15 min. Physically adsorbed ammonia was removed at 100 °C in a flow of dry helium for 1 h at a helium flow rate of 30 ml/min. For obtaining a TPD curve, the sample was cooled to 50–60 °C, and the temperature was gradually increased to 500 °C at the rate of 8 °C/min. The NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker AVANCE-II 400 spectrometer with a magnetic field of 9.4 T, which corresponds to 27Al operating frequencies of 104.23 MHz. The 27Al NMR spectra of air-dry samples were recorded with spinning at the magic angle (54.7°) with a frequency of 12 kHz and using the 4 mm ZrO2 rotor. The XPS analysis was performed on a Kratos Axis Ultra DLD. To excite photoelectrons, aluminum anode X-ray radiation was used (Al Kα = 1486.6 eV) with a tube voltage of 12 kV and emission current of 20 mA. 2.4 Hydrogenation of guaiacol and analysis of the reaction products The reaction was carried out in an autoclave facilities supplied by TIPS RAS (internal volume, 10 cm3) equipped with a magnetic stirrer and a manometer. The catalyst was preliminarily reduced in a flow reactor. The autoclave was filled with 25, 50 or 250 mg of a finely ground catalyst and 1 g of a substrate. A solution of 5 wt% GUA (Sigma–Aldrich, ≥98%) in dodecane (Sigma–Aldrich, ≥99%) or a solution of (20, 50wt%) GUA (Sigma–Aldrich, ≥98%) in methanol (Sigma–Aldrich, 99.8%) was used as a substrate. The autoclave was filled with hydrogen to the pressure of 5 MPa. The reaction was carried out in the temperature range of 200–400 °C with continuous stirring at 1000 rpm for a specified time (from 3 to 6 h). After completion of the reaction, the autoclave was rapidly cooled to room temperature, and the pressure was decreased to atmospheric pressure.Since noble metal catalysts are expensive, the reusability of catalysts are critical to the HDO of bio-oil. The catalyst was separated by decantation after the HDO of guaiacol in methanol, washed with acetone and drying at 100 °C for 4 h. The recovered catalyst was reused in the recycle run without any further treatment under 200 °C, 50 MPa H2 for 3 h. The quantitative analysis of the liquid products of guaiacol hydrogenation was carried out on a Kristall-Lyuks gas chromatograph with a flame-ionization detector and a PetrocolTM capillary column of 0.25 mm × 50 m (Supelco); helium was a carrier gas. The qualitative analysis of the liquid products was performed by GC–MS on a Finnigan MAT 95 XL instrument equipped with a chromatograph with a Varian VF-5MS capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 m); helium was a carrier gas (1.5 cm3/min). 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalyst characterization According to the data of the low-temperature adsorption/desorption of nitrogen, the materials obtained in the work were characterized by a high specific surface area (S sp), a large pore volume (V pore), and an average pore size (D pore) from 35 to 40 Å, as calculated from the adsorption data (Table 1 ). All of the Al-HMS(X) samples were characterized by the IV type adsorption/desorption isotherms with a loop, which confirm a mesoporous structure. The isotherm for m-ZrO2-SiO2 lies between type-I and type-IV (Fig. 1 ). The value of the average pore diameter of 4 nm conﬁrms that the material has mesoporosity. At low metal loading (∼1wt%), the surface characteristics remained unchanged after impregnation. The27Al NMR spectrum of Al-HMS(10) is typical for ordered mesoporous materials of this type (Fig. 2 a). It exhibits a line at 55 ppm from 4-coordinate aluminum and a line around 0 ppm from 6-coordinate aluminum [55]. There are several assignments for observed 30 ppm signal: distorted tetrahedral Al, pentacoordinated Al, or an overlap of both distorted four- and five-coordinated Al species [56]. The presence of peaks at 0 and 30 ppm indicates that some Al(III) ions can be excluded from the framework of Al-HMS. This non-framework aluminum is able to partially damage the hexagonal order and decrease the surface area. 29Si NMR spectrum of m-ZrO2-SiO2 (Fig. 2b) consists of 3 peaks at 100, 90 and 85 ppm which can be assigned to Q3, Q2 and Q1 structural forms, respectively. Qn represents Si(OSi)n(OH)4-n or Si(OSi)n(OZr)4-n and n = 1–3 indicated the connection of Si with hydroxyl groups or Zr atoms [55]. The Q4 [Si(SiO4)] form dominating in pure silica was not observed in 29Si NMR spectrum. The significant amounts of Q3 and Q2 indicate Zr incorporation into a silica framework. It is difficult to compare OH and OZr groups, because they have a similar inﬂuence on the chemical shift of the central Si atoms [57]. A spectrum with polarization transfer shows a sufficiently high concentration of Si-OH groups, which indicates the presence of defects. The acidic properties of catalysts are evaluated by NH3-TPD, as shown in Table 2 . The acidity of all supports synthesized in this work decreased in the order of m-ZrO2-SiO2 > Al-HMS(10) > Al-HMS(40) > Al-HMS(100) (Table 2, Fig. 3 ). Peaks at ∼200 °C peak detected for all samples were assigned to weak adsorption of ammonia. The acidity of the HMS samples was found to decrease with decreasing the aluminum content. With a decrease in the Si/Al ratio of Al/HMS(X) materials, a high-temperature peak at over 500 °C corresponding to strong acid centers was observed (Fig. 3). The acidity of the catalysts was measured for the samples exhibiting the greatest activity in the HDO of guaiacol (PtPd/Al-HMS(10), Ru/m-ZrO2-SiO2, PtPd/m-ZrO2-SiO2 and Ru/Al-HMS(10). After PtPd impregnation, the acidity increased insignificantly. After Ru impregnation on Al-HMS(10) acidity also increased, while Ru impregnation on m-ZrO2-SiO2 partially reduced acidity (Fig. S1). Ru particles can preferentially bonded to weak acid sites of the zirconia [58], which blocks acid sites and causes a decrease in acidity after Ru impregnation on ZrO2-SiO2 surface (Al-HMS(10) in addition to weak cites has a strong acid sites). Ru impregnation can contribute to the increase in acidity of aluminosilicate-based catalyst [59]. It should be noted that materials of the Al-HMS type possess some advantages over other supports based on mesoporous aluminosilicate. They are characterized by higher specific surface area, and their synthesis is performed under much milder conditions and within a shorter period of time [60]. CTMAB was used as a surfactant in the synthesis of m-ZrO2-SiO2 to obtain the most ordered materials with a narrow pore-size distribution, which did not contain alkali metal cations [61]. A considerable mesoporous structure degradation accompanied by a decrease in the specific surface area was observed on the calcination of mesoporous materials based on ZrO2 at temperatures of 450–500 °C. It was found that processing of mesoporous ZrO2 with various oxides (SiO2, Al2O3, WO3, P2O5) at the stage of synthesis increases the thermal stability, which leads to the production of materials with high specific surface area [10,61]. We proposed two-stage method for synthesis of materials based on mesoporous ZrO2 stabilized with SiO2 (Si/Zr = 1.3) to obtain materials stabled upon calcination 550 °C with narrow pore size distribution, which have large pore volumes and specific surface area. The mechanism of stabilization is still not clear. It is likely that stabilization occurs due to the incorporation of stabilizing agent particles into the defects of mesoporous structure of m-ZrO2. It can be assumed that the obtained material is a structured m-ZrO2 with particles of SiO2 distributed on its surface. The ordered hexagonal porous structures of the mesoporous materials obtained were confirmed by the TEM data. The hexagonal structure can be more clearly seen in the materials with lower aluminum contents (Fig. S2). Catalysts based on mesoporous materials were characterized by EDX spectrometer connected to electron microscope. The EDX spectra of different catalysts are shown in Supplementary Material (Fig. S3–S6). According to these data for PtPd-containing catalysts based on Al-HMS(10) and m-ZrO2-SiO2, small particles of an intermetallic compound of platinum and palladium with a diameter of 2–10 nm primarily occurred on the support surface; however, a small number of Pd and Pt particles with diameters to 20 nm was also present (Fig. 4 (a and b)). The average particle sizes of 1.1 ± 0.2 and 2.5 ± 0.4 nm for Ru/Al-HMS(10) and Ru/m-ZrO2-SiO2, respectively, were observed in the TEM images (Fig. 4(c and d)). A much narrower particle size distribution was obtained over Ru/Al-HMS(10), with most of the particles in the 1–2 nm range The XPS spectrum of Ru/m-ZrO2-SiO2 exhibits the lines of zirconium, silicon, carbon, and oxygen. Fig. 5 (a) shows a region of the high-resolution spectrum of Ru 3d electrons. The Ru 3d 5/2 binding energy is 280.1 eV and the Ru 3d 3/2 binding energy is 284.2 eV, which corresponds to ruthenium metal [62]. Signal at 280.8 eV corresponds to RuO2 [63]. Because of overlapping of the C 1s line (at ∼285 eV) with the Ru 3d3/2 line (at 285.1 eV), only the Ru 3d5/2 component (280.1 eV) can be identified reliably in Ru 3d XPS spectrum of Ru/Al-HMS(10), which corresponds to metallic Ru [62] (Fig. S7). Fig. 5(b) shows the XPS spectrum of PtPd/m-ZrO2-SiO2. In this spectrum, the lines of Pd 3d electrons are superimposed on the Zr 3p spectrum, and it is impossible to separate the Pd 3d lines against the background of intensive Zr 3p lines. In the Pt 4f XPS spectrum (Fig. 5(c)), it is possible to recognize two signals with Pt 4f7/2 binding energy of 71.0 eV and Pt 4f5/2 binding energy of 74.4 eV, which correspond to Pt° atoms [64,65]. Signals at 71.7 eV and 75.3 eV correspond to Pt2+ 4f7/2 and Pt2+ 4f5/2, respectively [66]. The ratio between the states of platinum is about 70:30. PtPd catalysts based on Al-HMS showed similar results. 3.2 Hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol in methanol over PtPd catalysts The supported metal catalysts were evaluated for the HDO of guaiacol as the CO bonds in this molecule are very difficult to break [67]. During the HDO of guaiacol on transition-metal-based catalysts the preferred formation of phenol and catechol and, to a lesser extent, benzene and cyclohexane were observed [68,69]. In comparison, the products formed after the HDO of guaiacol over noble metal catalysts were mainly composed of cyclohexane, benzene, methylcyclohexane and toluene (O-free products) [24,33,38]; cyclohexanol, 2-methoxycyclohexanol, cyclohexanediol, dimethoxycyclohehane et al. were reported as other HDO by-products [23,32]. In accordance with the HDO over noble metal catalysts using hydrocarbons as a solvent described in literature [24,70], the main products of guaiacol HDO in dodecane (200 °C, 50 MPa of H2) on all tested catalysts were 2-methoxycyclohexanol, cyclohexane and methylcyclohexane formed via hydrogenation of guaiacol on metal sites and, to a lesser extent, phenol and benzene formed via the sequential CAr O bond cleavage on acid cites (Fig. S7). High conversion achieved on tested catalysts are consistent with the data on high activity of catalysts supported on mesoporous materials such as HMS [40,71,72] and ZrO2 [23,73] in hydrogenation of bio-oil and its phenolic compounds. However, hydrocarbons, which are used as the solvent in the HDO of the model compounds, do not dissolve lignin-derived bio-oil [1,74]. Furthermore, a real bio-oil contains a considerable number of low-molecular-weight volatiles (methanol, acetic acid, formaldehyde, etc.), which affect the course of hydrogenation of lignin monomers, substantially decrease the activity of catalysts, and change the product distribution because of the occurrence of side reactions [49]. There are little data regarding the HDO of phenolic compounds over noble metal catalysts in the presence of methanol, however, they seem promising for their ability to activate hydrogen [67]. The major products of guaiacol HDO in the presence of alcohol are cyclohexanols [75,76] and phenols [51,77]. We tested PtPd-containing catalysts supported on mesoporous m-ZrO2-SiO2 and Al-HMS(10) in the liguid phase HDO of guaiacol in methanol due to speciﬁc physicochemical properties characteristic for these mesoporous materials. The effect of reaction temperature on the HDO of guaiacol over PtPd supported on Al-HMS catalyst was investigated, as shown in Table 3 . Reaction temperature has a significant effect on guaiacol conversion and product distribution [39,51]. Guaiacol conversion over PtPd-containing catalyst based on Al-HMS(100) in methanol reached only 4% at 200 °C (Table 3). A further increase in temperature caused a considerable increase in conversion. The quantitative conversion of guaiacol was reached at 400 °C; however, the main products were polymethylated phenols, catechols and cyclohexylphenols – heavy products of methylation and polymerization of aromatic rings [78]. Heavy products appeared in the presence of methanol already at 250 °C and might deposit on catalyst surface and cause deactivation [73]. In the temperature range of 250–400 °C the yields of ring-saturation products (cyclohexanes and cyclohexanoles) and catechol decreased with temperature, whereas the yields of phenol and polymethylated products increased. On the basis of the obtained results, it can be assumed that the role of reactions that take place at acid sites of the catalyst increases with temperature. A significant decrease in the yield of ring-saturation products with increasing temperature confirms that aromatic ring hydrogenation on metal active sites is preferable at sufficiently low temperatures and deoxygenation is favoured over hydrogenation at high temperatures [23,32]. The effect of the support acidity on the HDO of guaiacol was investigated using PtPd/Al-HMS(X) catalysts with different Si/Al ratio (X) as shown in Table 4 . The highest conversion was reached on the sample of PtPd/Al-HMS(10). As the concentration of acid sites on the support grew(Si/Al ratio decreased), the fraction of hydrogenated products (cyclohexanes and cyclohexanoles) reduced and the total yield of methylated phenols, catechols and cyclohexylphenols increased. It should be noted that with increasing the acidity of support the yield of catechol also increased. The experimental results showed that the main reactions in the presence of methanol occurred at acid sitesand were related to the processes of CArO–CH3 hydrogenolysis (catechol formation) and active methylation (cresols, xylenols, and polymethylated phenols and catechols predominated in the products distribution). It should be noted, as real bio-oil is currently effective upgraded at temperatures above 300 °C [1,20], acidity experiments were carried out at this temperature to evaluate the behavior of Al-HMS-based catalysts at elevated temperatures. The catalysts exhibited activity in the HDO of guaiacol even with small loadings after three hours of reaction. It should be taken into account, notwithstanding that the highest conversion value was obtained on the most acidic catalyst, high acidity negatively affects the liquid phase hydrodeoxygenation in methanol at elevated temperatures, which is expressed in the active methylation of intermediates and in the decrease in the yield of the target hydrogenated products. The effect of the catalyst loading on the HDO of guaiacol was investigated using PtPd-containing catalysts supported on Al-HMS(10) and m-ZrO2-SiO2, as shown in Table 5 . The development of adequate catalysts working under mild conditions is challenging for HDO of lignin-derived compounds. At 200 °C the degree of guaiacol conversion on both catalysts at a GUA/metal molar ratio of 800 (catalyst loading of 50 mg) did not exceed 5%. This low degree of conversion can be explained by the competition between methanol and guaiacol molecules for active sites of a catalyst on their joint adsorption. It is possible, that methanol is more actively adsorbed on the catalyst surface and blocks the access of the substrate to its active sites [49]. As methanol blocks active sites, methylation process prevails in the reaction and hydrodeoxygenation itself takes place to a low extent. Under low catalyst loading the main HDO products were anisole or phenol, hydrogenated alcohols and cresol. The preferred formation of anisole on the PtPd/Al-HMS(10) catalyst may be related to a lower acidity of the sample compared with that of PtPd/m-ZrO2-SiO2. In this case, a more thermodynamically stable methoxycarbocation is formed according to reaction (II), whereas the reaction can occur via both reaction paths (I) and (II) in the presence of more acidic PtPd/m-ZrO2-SiO2 (Fig. 6 ). The conversion of guaiacol sharply went up as the catalyst amount was increased (at a GUA/metal molar ratio of 160, catalyst loading of 0.25 g) (Table 5). This was due to an increase of the surface area and, therefore, an increase in the number of catalyst active centers free from methanol. An increase in catalyst concentration led to intense formation of fully hydrodeoxygenated products, cyclohexane and methylcyclohexane. While at low catalyst loading, the fraction of these products did not exceed 3%, with increased catalyst loading cyclohexane and methylcyclohexane became the main products of the HDO of guaiacol at 200 °C (60% and 51% for PtPd/Al-HMS(10) and PtPd/m-ZrO2-SiO2, respectively). Note that, upon the HDO of guaiacol on m-ZrO2-SiO2 (in the absence of metal), only polymethylated catechols and phenols were the reaction products, which confirms that aromatic ring hydrogenation occurs at metal active sites. The removal of palladium from the composition of the catalysts led to an increase in the heavy fraction of methylcatechols and cyclohexylphenols and then to a considerable decrease in conversion (Table S1). We investigated the effect of supports on the HDO of guaiacol at increased catalyst loading (Table 5). As a result of lower acidity of PtPd/Al-HMS(10) (317 μmol/g), the content of products formed during demethylation and dehydroxylation of guaiacol on acid sites (catechol and phenol) on this sample was lower than that on PtPd/m-ZrO2-SiO2 (481 μmol/g). Although the PtPd/Al-HMS(10) sample had a lower total number of acid sites, the fraction of polymethylated phenols and catechols formed on this sample was much higher (to 21%) than that on PtPd/m-ZrO2-SiO2 (11%). Probably, this was caused by the presence of strong acid sites in the mesoporous materials based on aluminum (Fig. 4) [55]. Despite a higher phenol content (11%), which indicated a higher deoxygenation ability of the catalyst based on m-ZrO2-SiO2, the yield of cyclohexane (38%) for PtPd/m-ZrO2-SiO2 was lower than that for Al-HMS(10)-based catalyst, which exhibited greater activity of PtPd/Al-HMS(10) catalyst in the hydrogenation of phenolic compounds in the presence of methanol. It should be noted, that PtPd catalyst based on nonmesoporous γ-Al2O3 did not show sufficient activity in the HDO of guaiacol in methanol, conversion reached only 7%. The main products were 2-methoxycyclohexanol (49%) and catechol (36%), therefore, effective deoxygenation and hydrogenation did not occur (Table S2). The effect of solvent concentration on the HDO of guaiacol was investigated based on the results presented above in Table 5, concerning the blocking of catalyst active sites with methanol. The molecular composition of bio-oil changes with use of different raw materials, production conditions and other influential factors. However, the relative ratio of methanol/guaiacol (GC–MS) in bio-oils does not exceed 4 [79]. Different methanol/guaiacol weight ratios (0/100, 50/50, 80/20, wt%) were used in the HDO of guaiacol over PtPd catalysts based on m-ZrO2-SiO2 (Table 6 ). During the HDO of pure guaiacol, cyclohexane (25%), catechol (28%), and polymethylated phenols (26%) were the main products, while the conversion was 11%. The HDO of guaiacol in a mixture with methanol (50/50) led to a sharp increase in conversion (69%) and also to an increase in the fraction of oxygen-containing aromatic compounds, in particular, phenol (14%), catechol (29%), and their methylation products (40%); the fraction of aromatic ring hydrogenation products (сyclohexanes, сyclohexanoles) considerably decreased (6%). Low conversion during the HDO of pure guaiacol was probably related to the fact that aromatic molecules can block active sites of noble metal catalysts, e.g. strong parallel adsorption of phenol on the Pd (111) surface can prevent further guaiacol adsorption [80]. Resasco et al. showed that the strong adsorption of double-functionalized guaiacol (or catechol) on the catalyst surface could block sites for deoxygenation on the Pt catalyst [81]. With a further increase in the methanol content (80/20), the conversion sharply reduced, probably due to the inhibitory effect of methanol on the activity of noble metal catalysts caused by competitive adsorption phenolic compound and/or H2 and alcohol molecules on the same active sites [44,49]. In accordance with the reaction equation: C6H5OCH3 (anisole) + H2O ⇄ C6H5OH (phenol) + CH3OH in the presence of excess methanol the equilibrium was shifted to the left towards the predominant formation of anisole and process of demethoxylation was reduced. The presence of only methylated derivatives (methylanisole, methylphenols) in the HDO products was related to active alkylation of phenolic compounds over catalysts based on CeO2 or ZrO2 materials, if alcohol was used as a solvent [82]. 3.3 Hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol in methanol over Ru catalysts Ru-containing catalysts can be highly active in hydrotreatment of bio-oil [20,21] and its phenolic compounds [24,54,83–88]. Aqueous phase HDO of guaiacol over Ru-containing catalyst generally results in predominant formation of cyclohexanol [86,87] or cyclohexane [24,84,88]. As is shown by Lee et al. [24] Ru/ZrO2 catalysts show enhanced activity in the liquid phase HDO of guaiacol in the presence of hydrocarbon to form preferably cyclohexane. In this work Ru/m-ZrO2-SiO2 and Ru/Al-HMS(10) were tested in the liquid phase HDO of guaiacol in the presence of methanol. The conversion of guaiacol in methanol at low catalyst loading was very low for the tested Ru-based catalysts as in case with the PtPd-based catalysts. With the increase in catalyst loading, Ru/Al-HMS(10) and Ru/m-ZrO2-SiO2 showed higher hydrodeoxygenation activity compared with that of PtPd-based catalysts, which resulted in a substantially increased fraction of cyclohexanes (Table 7 ). The HDO of guaiacol on these catalysts proceeds according to the patterns similar to those described above for PtPd catalysts (Table 5), with the exception of almost complete absence of the fraction of methylphenols, methylcatechols and cyclohexylphenols, especially for Ru/Al-HMS(10). This can be related to the fact that methanol is adsorbed more strongly on the PtPd surface [89], thus blocking its active sites, while methanol adsorbs readily on Ru (001) and decomposes at its surface even at low temperature [90]. As the reaction time was increased to 6 h, the quantitative conversion of guaiacol was achieved; a further increase in the fraction of fully hydrodeoxygenated products was observed (Table 7). The cyclohexane selectivity increased, while methylcyclohexane selectivity decreased, which indicated its further demethylation at the acid sites of the catalyst in the process of time. However, inspite of the significant increase in yield of cyclohexanes, the fraction of undesired methylphenols and methylcatechols appears in reaction products with increasing reaction time of the HDO of guaiacol in methanol. At large catalyst loading, the conversion of guaiacol over all tested Ru catalysts already at 200 °C was more than 80%; with the increase in temperature, a quantitative conversion was achieved (Table 8 ). Reaction temperature has a pronounced effect on product distribution. When the temperature was raised to 250 °C an insignificant increase in the content of cyclohexanes via sequential deoxygenation of methoxycyclohexanol was observed. Due to the reactions of transmethylation in the presence of methanol, methylphenols appeared in the reaction products at 250 °C. With further increase in temperature, the selectivity for cyclohexanes decreased significantly, while selectivity for cyclohexanols remained relatively high, which indicates a sharp decrease in the rate of deoxygenation at the acid centers of the catalysts at temperatures above 300 °C. Moreover, the fraction of methylphenols and methylcatechols continues to grow, implying that during the HDO of guaiacol in methanol at high temperatures, the process of transmethylation on acid sites predominates. Bicyclic compounds also appeared in the products at high temperatures due to high acidity of the tested catalysts [73]. Ru/Al-HMS(10) catalyst showed the best activity in the HDO of guaiacol at 200 °C in the presence of methanol, which was expressed in the highest guaiacol conversion (85%), the greatest selectivity for the desired product cyclohexane (62%), and the smallest fraction of methylation products (1%). This activity can probably be explained by small sizes of Ru nanoparticles and their high dispersion on the aluminosilicate surface (Fig. 4) associated with the oxophilic nature of ruthenium [54,91]. 3.4 Catalyst recycle study Two catalysts (PtPd/Al-HMS(10) and Ru/m-ZrO2-SiO2) were used in the HDO of guaiacol under the same conditions (200 °C, 5 MPa H2, GUA/metal ratio of 160) for the second run cycle (Table S3). Catalyst recycling experiments, performed without regeneration, showed that catalysts were active during reusability experiment, however, the average pore volume and the BET surface area of spent catalysts decreased (Table S4). In both experiments the conversion dropped after the first cycle, indicating catalyst deactivation. In the case of Ru/m-ZrO2-SiO2 catalyst conversion fell significantly. Metal active sites were poisoned by methanol, which was expressed in a sharp decrease in selectivity of cyclohexanes for Ru/m-ZrO2-SiO2 (to 3%) and less dramatic for PtPd/Al-HMS(10) (to 24%). The deactivation trend of the catalysts was different from the types of noble metal: bimetallic catalysts may exhibit higher deactivation resistance as compared to the monometallic samples [92]. In addition, supported Ru catalysts was more prone to deactivation than Pd catalysts [93]. Greater destruction of mesoporous structure of support during deactivation, confirmed by BET measurements, was observed for Ru/m-ZrO2-SiO2 sample, which is related with decrease in the fraction of products formed on acid sites (phenols and catechols). The presence of a significant amount of methylated phenols and catechols in products obtained on PtPd/Al-HMS(10) indicates the occurrence of reactions at acid sites, but its deoxygenation activity is reduced due to deactivation process. The mechanism of deactivation could be caused by occupation of pore channels by oligomerization products, which may block acid sites of catalyst. 3.5 Pathways of the liquid phase HDO of quaiacol in methanol The HDO of guaiacol can proceed via two parallel reaction routes [94,95]. One of them is hydrogenation of aromatic ring on metal sites; the other one is demethylation with the formation of catechol or demethoxylation directly to phenol with subsequent deoxygenation occurring on acid sites of the catalyst [96]. According to these pathways, the obtained experimental data suggest that the HDO of guaiacol on catalysts containing both metal and acid sites occurs through several parallel pathways (Fig. 7 ): aromatic ring hydrogenation accompanied by the removal of OH groups (route (A)) and demethoxylation and dehydroxylation reactions followed by hydrogenation to cyclohexane in accordance with route (B). The CO bond energies in a guaiacol molecule decrease in the order: CAr – OH (414 kJ mol−1) > CAr – OCH3(356 kJ mol−1) > CArO – CH3 (247 kJ mol−1) [73]. The first step of guaiacol HDO at acid sites should follow the demethylation route, which is confirmed by the presence of a significant amount of catechol in the reaction products (route (B1)). Theoretically, the CAr – OH could be activated easily on the active sites of a catalyst due to the minimal steric hindrance effect. However, the bond energy of CAr – OH is the strongest among the three types of CO bonds of guaiacol molecule, so anisole is rarely mentioned in literature as a reaction product [7,25,97]. In our case, when methanol was used as a solvent, anisole was detected in reaction products. At a ratio of methanol/guaiacol of 80/20 wt% (Table 6), methylanisole was found in the reaction products, suggesting that in the presence of methanol, methycyclohexane was formed by the acid-catalyzed methyl group transfer to the anisole molecule, followed by demethoxylation and hydrogenation (route (B2)). Another important feature of HDO in the presence of methanol is active methylation with the formation of polymethylphenols, polymethylcatechols and cyclohexylphenols (route (C)), which can be inhibited by selecting the catalyst and the optimal reaction conditions. 4 Conclusions In this work, the liquid phase HDO of guaiacol using methanol as a solvent was first studied over PtPd and Ru catalysts, supported on mesoporous Al-HMS or m-ZrO2-SiO2. Reaction pathways of guaiacol HDO on tested catalysts were investigated. The important feature of the liquid phase HDO of guaiacol in methanol was active methylation of intermediates on acid sites of the catalyst with the formation of heavy polymethylphenols, polymethylcatechols and cyclohexylphenols, which can be inhibited by selecting a catalyst with optimal acidity and suitable reaction conditions. Thus, an increase in temperature above 250 °C led to active methylation of the HDO intermediates (route C) and to a sharp decrease in the selectivity for cyclohexanes formed via route A, which, in turn, can be the components for bio-based liquid transportation fuel. With increasing concentration of acid sites in the catalysts based on Al-HMS (Si/Al ratio decreases from 100 to 10) conversion increased and fraction of phenol, catechol, and their methylated derivatives grew in products of guaiacol transformation (route B). With a small catalyst loading the HDO of guaiacol proceeded mainly via two major routes (B and C). An increase in the catalyst loading provided the hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol mostly via route A. Due to the higher acidity, the deoxygenation ability of m-ZrO2-SiO2 support is higher, but the process of hydrogenation in the presence of this support is less active, compared with Al-HMS(10) support. Ru-containing catalysts exhibited higher activity in the HDO of guaiacol than PtPd-containing catalysts. The highest selectivity toward cyclohexanes of 63 and 77% was achieved on Ru/m-ZrO2-SiO2 and Ru/Al-HMS(10) catalysts, respectively (200 °C, 5 MPa H2, 3 h). coredata.dc:description: The liquid phase hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of guaiacol (GUA), a model compound of bio-oil, was studied on bimetallic (PtPd) and monometallic (Ru) catalysts supported on mesoporous aluminosilicate of Al-HMS(X) type with different Si/Al (X) ratios and on mesoporous zirconia modified with silica (m-ZrO2-SiO2) in the presence of methanol as a solvent. The catalysts were characterized by NH3-TPD, TEM, XPS, 27Al and 29Si solid-state NMR and N2 adsorption–desorption methods. The inﬂuence of сatalyst loading, temperature, solvent/guaiacol ratio and contact time on the catalytic performance was investigated. It was established that, decreasing the Si/Al ratio and, correspondingly, increasing the acidity of the catalysts based on Al-HMS led to increasing conversion of guaiacol. Phenol, catechol, and their methylated derivatives were the main products of guaiacol HDO reaction in methanol at low catalyst loading (guaiacol/metal ratio, 800). It was found that the fraction of completely hydrodeoxygenated products (cyclohexane and methylcyclohexane) greatly increased as the catalyst loading grew (guaiacol/metal ratio, 160). Conversion of guaiacol on PtPd/m-ZrO2-SiO2 catalyst was higher than that on PtPd/Al-HMS(10), in accordance with the larger number of acid sites on the catalyst surface; however, the undesirable heavy fraction of methylated by-products was also higher. Ru-based catalysts exhibited the highest catalytic activity and showed unusually high selectivity toward fully hydrodeoxygenated products (cyclohexane, methylcyclohexane) in the HDO of guaiacol in the presence of methanol. Guaiacol can be efficiently converted into alkanes, with quantitative conversion and selectivity to cyclohexanes of 78% over Ru/Al-HMS(10) catalyst under relatively mild conditions (200 °C, 5 MPa H2). Methylation under the influence of methanol, deoxygenation on acid sites and aromatic ring hydrogenation on metal sites proceeded in a parallel way according to the suggested reaction pathways.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol as a model compound of bio-oil in methanol over mesoporous noble metal catalysts
